The governor‚Äôs office wants to place a provision into the state‚Äôs $230 billion budget that would change how the state counts methane emissions, allowing energy companies to include more natural gas in their energy mix while still complying with the state‚Äôs climate law.
‚ÄúThe governor and her administration‚Äôs track record of decisive action to move away from fossil fuels toward a zero-emission economy speaks for itself,‚Äù two Hochul administration officials

in an op-ed supporting the proposed change on Monday. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre confident that the final budget will shape up to include historic climate commitments ‚Äî including an economy-wide cap-and-invest program, ways to accelerate our development of renewable energy and our transition to all-electric buildings ‚Äî so we can ultimately reach our climate goals while ensuring affordability for New York families.‚Äù

In 2019, New York passed the Climate Leadership and Community Protection Act (CLCPA), which stipulated the most ambitious requirements in the country for how quickly the state should decarbonize its economy. The CLCPA requires the state to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 40 percent by 2030, and achieve net-zero emissions by 2050.

Under the CLCPA, the state calculates the impact of climate emissions over a 20-year period ‚Äî one of only two states that does so. Hochul‚Äôs proposed change would revise that to a 100-year period.

The provision would benefit natural gas producers and utilities, because it would impact how methane, the primary component of natural gas, is treated by the law. While methane lingers in the atmosphere for a much shorter time period than carbon dioxide, the gas has
the warming power of carbon dioxide in the first 20 years after it is released.
